page.title: 18Currying in Sowerby
page.content: Tanned leather has been dressed, or curried, at 'The Tannery ' in Sowerby since 1815. After retanning, the hide is separated from the underlying skin by a continuous blade,called a slicer. Then, as leather is bought by weight and sold by area, it is then stretched and flattened by the 250 ton pressure of a plating machine, which can also give the leather the pattern of crocodile or pigskin. Sanded and dyed, the finished leather is sold to be made into weight-lifter's belts,dog collars and upholstery. Currying requires that the hide be dried and remoistened between each stage,so that the whole process takes between 4 and 6 weeks.Currying is an ancient process which employs both old and new methods One ingenious machine,invented in 1915 is still used in measuring area.
